Graphical abstract The correlation between surface acidity-basicity and catalyst deactivation have been investigated in the CO2 reforming of methane by adjusting the surface properties of the catalyst. Silica and alumina based support with different acidity-basicity have been prepared by two methods, (i) a solvothermal method and (ii) a sequential impregnation method. Then each of the supports has been decorated with Ni nanoparticles followed by variation of their activity towards CO2 reforming of methane (DRM). The catalytic materials have been analyzed before and after reaction by a variety of analytical techniques including BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, O2-TPD, TG, O2-TPO, H2-TPH, SEM, and TEM. Catalysts with higher acidity were found to promote methane-cracking reactions, while the Boudouard and deactivation owing to metal oxidation were dominant at high basicity. Catalysts with more acidic or basic surfaces were found to be more prone to deactivation and metal sintering. The turnover frequency (TOF) and activation energy (Ea) of both the reactants showed a Gaussian curve with acidity-basicity of the catalyst surfaces. Among the tested catalysts, the best performing was those with homogeneous dispersion of surface acidic and basic sites, prepared by a single step synthesis. In contrast, under the same conditions, two-step synthesized supports with the significantly imbalanced distribution of acidic and basic sites favoured the Reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, active metal oxidation by surface adsorbed oxygen and hence deactivated rapidly. Keywords Dry reforming Metal support interaction Surface acidity-basicity Kinetics 1 Introduction In most countries, the consumption of non-renewable fossil fuels, as the primary energy source, produces vast quantities of CO2. The buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere is, in part, responsible for rapid changes in the climate and consequently for severe environmental impacts. Therefore, processes for the production of green, renewable, eco-friendly energy are in demand [1,2]. The utilization of atmospheric CO2 is one approach that is being pursued. Rapid advances in natural gas extraction technologies have made available large quantities of methane, and consequently, processes that convert methane into higher value products are of great interest in the present scenario [3]. The conversion of methane into higher value products can be achieved directly, but is more commonly performed via synthesis gas (syngas) as an intermediate [4]. Syngas is an intermediate for some critical industrial processes such as the synthesis of methanol, oxygenates and in FT synthesis [5,6]. Of the numerous natural gas reforming techniques available, CO2 reforming of methane also known as the Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) has attracted great interest, since the process utilizes two abundant carbon containing feedstock, CH4 and CO2, and yields syngas with an H2/CO ratio equal to unity which is suitable for use in important chemical processes such as FT synthesis for liquid fuel and chemical production. The reaction is also suitable for energy storage and transmission [7]. Despite its potential in both energy and material applications, to date, the DRM has not been implemented in industry, and there are no commercial catalysts available. This is primarily due to limited catalyst lifetime, which results from coke deposition and metal sintering. The development of an industrially acceptable catalyst for the DRM is an ongoing challenge. For such a catalyst to be acceptable from an economic perspective, it must be based on an inexpensive active metal. Noble metals, often incorporated in research catalysts, are not suitable owing to their high cost and limited availability. Due to such economic and environmental constraints, the substitution of noble metals with less expensive alternatives is demanding. Therefore, researchers have demonstrated the use of supported nickel catalysts in the DRM owing to its high intrinsic activity, availability and low cost. Some studies have demonstrated that the nature of the support has a strong influence on the catalytic performance of supported nickel catalysts in the DRM [8]. Metal support interactions have also been shown to influence the rate of carbon growth, as does the crystallite size and metal dispersion. Such characteristics can be affected by the acidity-basicity of the catalyst support. Consequently, the surface acidity-basicity can be used to tune the activity of a catalyst in the DRM. For example, it is known that an acidic support usually promotes cracking of methane, and thus leads to carbon formation. Conversely, the introduction of basicity into a catalyst is known to suppress carbon formation. However, other effects may also be introduced, for example, increasing basicity can also cause catalyst deactivation through the promotion of the Boudouard reaction in parallel with surface metal oxidation [9,10] and RWGS reaction. Hence, the balance between acid and basic sites plays a crucial role in determining long term catalyst stability. A recent investigation by Lovell et al. [11] showed that addition of either Al to promote support acidity or Na to reduce the support acidity into the Ni-MCM-41 framework changed the behaviour of the catalyst in the DRM. As well as affecting the methane conversion, the extent to which the various side reactions occurred was also altered. This demonstrated the potential for surface acidity to be tailored to optimize both product selectivity and catalyst lifetime. Youn et al. also studied nickel catalysts on various metal oxides as support with variable acidity [12], in this study of the autothermal reforming of ethanol, it was found that the H2 yield over the supported catalyst followed a volcano shaped distribution, with moderate acidity found to produce the best catalytic activity. Guo et al. [13] studied the effect of surface acidity upon catalytic activity in the DRM. They showed that MgAl2O4 with moderate acidity/basicity effectively suppressed the phase transformation to form the NiAl2O4 spinel phases and could stabilize tiny Ni crystallites. The catalyst showed high activity in the DRM. However, with increasing basicity, a portion of amorphous MgO became crystalline, which not only reduced the exposed active metal sites by covering the metal surface but also caused a significant change in the support characteristics, with the acceleration of both the surface metal sintering and carbon deposition, as observed by Shi et al. [14]. Theofanidis et al. [15] reported that the bimetallic Fe-Ni alloy upon MgAl2O4 effectively reduced coke formation up to 900K due to its low acidity. In comparison to Al2O3, it showed resistance to sintering, due to the strong interaction of the metal oxides with MgAl2O4, which resulted in the high metal dispersion. Similarly, in our previous study over modified alumina supported Ni catalysts [16], we have confirmed that the addition of ceria and magnesia to alumina reduced its acidity, and promoted the homogeneous distribution of nickel particles upon the support. This was found to favor stronger metal-support interactions, which produced better catalytic activity and less coke deposition when applied for the DRM. In this report, we set out to identify possible correlations between the support surface acid-base properties and catalyst deactivation for the DRM. To achieve this, modified silica and alumina catalyst supports have been prepared by both a single step and a two-step approach. On each of these supports, nickel nanoparticles have been deposited by a simple urea deposition-precipitation method, and deployed as catalysts for the DRM. The materials in both fresh as well as in spent form have been thoroughly characterised to establish whether there is any relationship between the surface properties and deactivation. Moreover, a kinetic analysis of activation energy variation with support acidity-basicity as well as a plausible mechanism have also been demonstrated for catalytic deactivation of DRM reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Aluminium isopropoxide, magnesium nitrate, hexahydrate, cerium nitrate hexahydrate, nickel nitrate hexahydrate, P123 (EO20PO70EO20), tetraethyl orthosilicate, fumed silica and magnesia were used as obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Ltd. Anhydrous ethanol (>99%) from Fisher Scientific and distilled water were used during this experiment. 2.1.1 Preparation of one step modified alumina Modified alumina (doped with 1% Cerium-3% Magnesia) and modified silica (doped with 1% Cerium-3% Magnesia) supports were prepared as previously described [16] and by the procedure of Fu et al. [17]. In a typical synthesis procedure for modified alumina, an ethanolic solution containing 6g of P123, 0.03g cerium nitrate hexahydrate, and 0.19g magnesium nitrate hexahydrate were added to an acidified ethanolic solution of 3.84g aluminium isopropoxide. The resultant mixture was well stirred and then evaporated to dryness at 333K over 48h before calcination at 973K for 6h. This was denoted as one step synthesized modified alumina. Normal alumina was prepared by the same procedure, however, without the addition of the metal precursors. 2.1.2 Preparation of one step modified silica In the case of modified silica, an ethanolic solution of 6g P123, 0.03g cerium nitrate hexahydrate, 0.19g magnesium nitrate hexahydrate was well stirred with 3.30g of tetraethyl orthosilicate, followed by evaporated to dryness at 333K over 48h and calcined at 673K for 2h. This type of silica was denoted as one step synthesized modified silica. Normal silica was prepared by the same procedure, without the addition of the metal precursors. 2.1.3 Preparation of two step modified alumina and silica Each of the normal silica and alumina samples was also doped with 1% cerium and 3% magnesia by simple impregnation procedure involving rotatory evaporation at 363K for 6h. These samples were then calcined in a muffle furnace at 973K for 6h and 673K for 2h for alumina and silica respectively. Due to the difference in the preparation methods, these impregnated supports were denoted as two step synthesized modified silica and alumina, respectively. 2.1.4 Ni deposition upon the support Each of the support was loaded with 5% Nickel via a urea deposition-precipitation approach. In a typical synthesis procedure 0.25g of Nickel nitrate hexahydrate and 0.95g of the support were heated with 0.25g of urea solution at 368K for 48h, the solid product was then filtered, washed with ethanol, dried at 373K and calcined at 673K for 4h, as described in our previous report [16]. The final products, i.e., Catalysts with 5% Ni upon supports were denoted as OsNiAl and OsNiSi with the one step synthesized alumina and silica support, and TsNiAl and TsNiSi with the two step synthesized alumina and silica support respectively. 2.1.5 Commercial supported catalysts For better comparison of surface acidity-basicity, Ni upon commercial silica and commercial magnesia was prepared from commercial silica and magnesia by urea deposition-precipitation approach and designated as Ni/com silica and Ni/com MgO. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The nature of the porosity of the metal loaded catalysts was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 93K (Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area & Porosity Analyzer) using the BET equation. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model of cylindrical pore was applied for the determination of pore size distribution. The catalyst was degassed before each measurement at 623K in a vacuum. Proto Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation connected with a Lynx eye high speed strip detector was used to determine the phase constitution in the range of 2θ=10-80 °. The valance state of nickel was performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using Thermo Scientific K-Alpha XPS instrument. The binding energies (±0.1eV) were calibrated with respect to the C 1s binding energy peak at 284.6eV. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis was carried out in a Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector in the temperature range of 373–1273K with a heating rate of 10Kmin−1 using helium as the carrier gas. The oxygen storage capacity of the catalysts was tested by following the procedure of Kim et al. [18] after reduction of the sample at 1273K in Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920, the sample was cooled down to 973K. Then a pulse of 5% O2 balance He was injected after every 3min, until the breakthrough curve obtained, which provided the total OSC of the sample. The Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) to characterize the morphologies of the synthesized samples was done using an FEI Quanta 200F instrument. The Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of both fresh and spent catalysts were recorded on a FEI Tecnai F30 transmission electron microscope. The catalysts were dispersed in ethanol for 15min in a sonication bath and mounted over a Cu grid for analysis. Differential thermogravimetric and Thermogravimetric analyses (DTG and TGA) were carried out using TGA 4000 (Perkin Elmer) instrument in the temperature range of 298–1123K with 10Kmin−1 ramping rate in nitrogen atmosphere. The carbon content of the fresh and spent catalysts was examined via elemental analysis technique using an Elemental Analyzer Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN analyzer. The coke accumulated over spent catalysts surface were quantified by Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) and Temperature programmed hydrogenation (TPH). After 100h reaction study the catalysts were heated from 323 to 1273K at a rate of 10Kmin−1 in an 10% O2/Ar mixture and an 10% H2 balance Ar (30mLmin−1). The effluent gases derived from deposited carbon were monitored with a thermal conductivity detector connected with Agilent gas-analyzer 7890B. 2.3 Catalyst performance investigation The catalytic activity of acid-base delimited Ni catalysts in the CO2 reforming of methane was examined in a downflow tubular quartz reactor, under atmospheric pressure with 200mg of the catalyst. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in situ at 1073K for 2h with 10% H2 in Ar. After reduction, the temperature was dropped, and the catalytic performance was investigated at 773–1073K with varying GHSV from 5000 to 50000mLg−1 h−1 with a constant molar gas mixture composition of CH4: CO2: He=1: 1: 8. The gas flow rates were controlled by using Bronkhost mass flow controller for the respective gases. The effluent gas was analyzed with an online Agilent 7890B GC analyzer, equipped with a plot alumina column for detection of methane in FID detector and a molsieve column connected with porapack Q column for the detection of H2, CO, CO2 and H2O in TCD. Methane and carbon dioxide conversions were determined according to Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. The H2/CO ratio in syngas at the outlet was calculated according to Eq. (3), and the turnover frequencies (TOF) for methane and carbon dioxide were computed according to Eqs. (4) and (5) and the carbon balance according to Eq. (6) [19]. (1) X C H 4 ( F CH 4 , in − F CH 4 , out ) F CH 4 , in × 100 (2) X C O 2 = ( F CO 2 , in − F CO 2 , out ) F CO 2 , in × 100 (3) H 2 CO = F H 2 , out F CO , out (4) TOF CH 4 = F CH 4 , in − F CH 4 , out 22400 × 60 × m (5) TOF CO 2 = F CO 2 , in − F CO 2 , out 22400 × 60 × m (6) Carbon balance ( % ) = F C H 4 o u t + F C O 2 o u t + F C O o u t F C H 4 i n + F C O 2 i n × 100 Where X CH 4 and X CO 2 are the percentage conversion of each component. F CH 4 , in , F CH 4 , out , F CO 2 , in , F CO 2 , out , F H 2 , out and FCO,out are the inlet and outlet flow of respective reactant gases (mLmin−1),m is the molar amount of metal in catalyst surface. To observe the effect of surface acidity-basicity upon the activation energy of methane and carbon dioxide, a kinetic study was also performed with 200mg of catalyst in a fixed bed microreactor with a total feed flow of 54mLmin−1, at a temperature range of 613–673K. The partial pressures values of the reactant gases (CH4 and CO2) and the balance gas He, were provided in the supporting information (Table 1s). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the fresh catalysts The pore size distributions for the freshly calcined catalyst and support materials, along with N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms are presented in Fig. 1 a and 1b. The textural parameters for these catalysts are presented in Table 1 . The effect of the catalyst surface nature, in terms of acidity-basicity upon the textural properties of the fresh catalysts, has been observed from this analysis. Both the one-step and two-step synthesized acid-base delimited Ni catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops, as shown in Fig. 1b, according to the IUPAC classification [17,20]. A sharp step has been observed in the isotherms at P/P0 =0.6 in all the alumina based catalysts, and at P/P0 =0.8 for silica based Ni catalysts, suggesting the existence of cylindrical mesopores and therefore a high BET surface area was registered for all the catalysts. In comparison with pure silica OsSi and pure alumina OsAl, the sorption value shifted slightly to a lower P/P0, which is a clear indication of confinement of the nickel nanoparticles, largely inside the pores, resulting in a decrease in average pore size. All the catalysts showed a slight shift of the P/P0 to a lower value, indicating the confinement of the nickel particles inside the mesopores. This have been also confirmed from the lowering of BET value. In contrast to the one step synthesized catalysts, the isotherms of two-step synthesized catalysts TsNiSi, and TsNiAl are not steep, indicating uniformity of the pores have been partly inhibited by the addition of metal within the mesoporous framework. The maximum value for pore condensation, i.e., the amount of N2 adsorbed over all the one-step, and two-step synthesized nickel catalyst is less than the corresponding support materials, which is again consistent with the presence of the metallic nickel inside the pores. Catalysts with higher BET surface area provide larger contact area for reactants and consequently higher reaction activity. The two-step synthesized impregnated catalysts (TsNiAl and TsNiSi) are found to have smaller surface areas in comparison with the one-step synthesized catalysts (OsNiAl and OsNiSi). For the two-step synthesized materials, the surface area has been decreased owing to the partial blockage of the pores by ceria and magnesia. Compare to mesoporous silica and alumina (OsSi and OsAl), the significant decrease in specific surface area and pore volume have been observed for all Ni supported catalysts as showed in Table 1. The decline in surface area can be ascribed to a rise in the density of catalysts due to the incorporation of nickel into the mesopores of the support. The insertion of nickel nanoparticles caused a slight reduction in average pore diameter of OsAl and OsSi. The nature of the reduction pattern and number of reducible species present on the catalyst surface have been measured using hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Fig. 2 a shows the H2-TPR profile of the one-step and two-step synthesized modified silica and modified alumina catalyst samples. The reducibility of the catalyst also provides information regarding the metal support interaction. According to previous literature reports, reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 occurs in a single step, without any intermediate at 568K [21]. Hence, the hydrogen consumption peaks those appeared at different temperature regions can be attributed to the reduction of Ni particles in various environments. Increasing acidity increases the interaction between metal species and acid sites of the support. Hence, metal sites become more electron deficient (Lewis acid), resulting in the formation of electron deficient sites on the modified silica and modified alumina surfaces. Therefore, increased support acidity leads to increased electron deficiency in the catalyst. All the catalysts exhibit similar profiles for hydrogen reduction and exhibit two pronounced reduction peaks at around 700K and at 973K. The first peak appeared at relatively low temperature (∼ 700K) due to the free large NiO particles which are unable to form chemical bonds with the underlying support surface. The reduction peak at 814K is assigned to the highly dispersed Ni2+ species interacting with the support surface. However, in the one-step synthesized Ni supported modified alumina catalyst another peak is apparent at 973K, which can be attributed to the nickel species strongly interacting with the alumina matrix. The hydrogen TPR quantitative analysis report is shown in Table 2 . The total hydrogen consumption values are in accord with the theoretical H2 uptake for all the one-step and two-step synthesized modified silica and alumina catalysts, suggesting that the Ni2+ species are completely reduced, under the operating condition. The distribution and strength of acidic and basic sites with support preparation technique have been determined by NH3 and CO2 TPD analysis (shown in Fig. 2b and c). Deconvolution of the TPD profiles for nickel nanoparticle doped one-step synthesized silica/alumina (OsNiAl, OsNiSi) and the two-step synthesized analogues (TsNiAl, TsNiSi), reveal that each NH3 and CO2 profile comprise of three peaks, two small peaks at ca ∼373 and 473K and a larger peak at ca. ∼773K. The amount of surface adsorbed ammonia and carbon dioxide have been determined by the total peak area of NH3 and CO2, and the results of these analyses are summarised in Table 3 . For ammonia TPD experiments, the desorption has been performed at lower temperature as at higher temperature ammonia may react with nickel to form nickel nitride [22]. Ammonia desorption for the various catalysts follows the trend Ni/Com silica>OsNiAl>OsNiSi>TsNiAl>TsNiSi>Ni/Com MgO. The one-step synthesized, modified silica and alumina based catalysts shows higher acidity than those based on two-step synthesized silica and alumina. This behaviour can be attributed to the synthesis procedure. In the one-step synthesized process, cerium nitrate, magnesium nitrate and aluminium isopropoxide all were added simultaneously to the solution. This provides insertion of metal particles inside the primary micelles at the colloidization stage, which furnish a better distribution of the metallic particles into the matrix as well as the better distribution of acidic and basic sites. In the two-step synthesized process, after the preparation of silica/alumina framework, ceria and magnesia were incorporated into this framework. Therefore the distribution of basic ceria and magnesia over this acidic framework is not homogeneous and hence, it provides a random distribution of basic sites upon the acidic silica or alumina framework, which reduces the surface acidity in the stepwise synthesized nickel catalysts [23]. Inspection of Fig. 2c shows that the amount of the adsorbed carbon dioxide is greatly influenced by the type of support and preparation procedure. The amount of the carbon dioxide adsorbed decreased in the order of Ni/Com MgO>OsNiAl>OsNiSi>TsNiAl>TsNiSi>Ni/Com silica which indicates, carbon dioxide adsorption behaviour of the catalysts varied depending upon nature of the support. The increase in adsorbed CO2, due to high basicity, results in more oxygen species on the surface of the catalysts, which enhances the gasification of carbon produced during CH4 dehydrogenation, thus supporting coke-free reforming [24]. With the surface acidity and basicity determined by NH3 and CO2 TPD, the surface acid/base ratio of the prepared catalysts have been determined, and the results are provided in Table 3. The homogeneous distribution of surface acidic/basic sites for the one-step synthesized catalysts shows acid/base ratios of ∼1.73–1.90. While stepwise synthesized catalysts, with irregular distribution of acidic and basic sites, diverge from this value and thus promote side reactions with lesser stability in the DRM [25]. Table 3 shows the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of the support materials. The OSC of different surfaces follows the trend Ni/Com MgO>OsNiAl>OsNiSi>TsNiAl>TsNiSi>Ni/Com silica. Ceria is a popular species for the storage of oxygen due to its variable oxidation states between +3 to +4. The reversible reduction of ceria owing to its variable valence is considered as the main reason for its high OSC [26]. The presence of ceria also hinders the thermally induced sintering of the catalyst support and enhances the coke removal process. This occurs due to the reaction of carbonaceous species adsorbed on the noble metal surface, with lattice oxygen in the modified alumina or silica surfaces. The partially reduced ceria can be reoxidized by gaseous oxidants, present in the reaction system [27]. Wang et al. reported that ceria and ceria-based mixed oxide catalysts have oxygen vacancies which make them excellent support for CO2 activation [28]. The effect of surface acidity-basicity upon oxygen storage capacity is observed from Table 3, where the enhanced oxygen storage capacity increases the durability of the catalysts under reducing environment [29,30]. The morphology of the catalysts, prepared by both one-step and a two-step synthesis procedures has been investigated by the use of scanning electronic microscopy (SEM), as shown in Fig. 3 and with transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as shown in Fig. 4 . The SEM images confirm that the morphology is independent of the synthesis procedure. The alumina based samples show a sponge like morphology with an average size 500nm, while that of the silica based catalysts show amorphous nature, however, the metal particle size has been strongly affected by the surface environment. In both one step synthesized silica alumina catalyst (OsNiSi and OsNiAl), the homogeneous distribution of acidic and basic sites favoured strong nickel support interaction which formed small nickel particle size ∼5nm. In both the stepwise synthesized silica and alumina (TsNiSi and TsNiAl) catalyst owing to weak metal support interaction, and improper distribution of acidic and basic sites, the nickel particle size has been obtained around ∼ 8–10nm. In commercially available silica, magnesia surface, owing to very weak metal support interaction, the nickel particle size increases to ∼ 20nm. Fig. 5 shows elemental mapping the one-step and two-step synthesized modified silica and modified alumina surfaces and the corresponding elemental mapping of each element present in the catalyst shown in supporting info. The distribution of each element has been shown with different colors. In both the one-step synthesized materials, nickel is in intimate contact with ceria, magnesia, and alumina while for the two-step synthesized materials the majority of nickel particles are in contact with either silica or alumina. These results indicate that the dispersal of each element depends significantly on the catalyst synthesis procedure. The one-step synthesis approach provides a uniform distribution of metal particles upon the support than the two-step approach. Thermal analysis of nickel supported one step, and stepwise synthesized catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . The analysis of one-step synthesized catalysts show an overall weight loss of ∼8% upon heating up to 873K. Whereas, both the two-step synthesized modified alumina and modified silica supported nickel catalysts show an overall weight loss ∼15% upon heating to 873K. The weight of the catalysts appear nearly constant on further increasing the temperature. This indicates that above 873K, no phase change occurs as well as no impurities are present in the sample. Analysis of the products evolved have not been performed in this study. However, based on previous literature [31,32]. and the DTG curve, the observed weight loss can be associated with the elimination of adsorbed water, 373–523K, and a phase change from Ni(OH)2 to NiO, up to 673K. The observed weight loss has been found much higher for two-step synthesized catalysts than the one-step synthesized catalysts which clearly indicates the higher stability of one-step synthesized catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic performances The effect of catalyst surface acidity-basicity on the CO2 reforming of methane has been investigated where DRM typically produces syngas with an H2/CO ratio of 1. Fig. 7 shows the effect of the surface nature on the catalytic activity as a function of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) and temperature, and the corresponding values are specified in supporting information (Tables 3s and 4s respectively). The catalytic activity has been found to be dependent upon both the parameters. The impact of contact time, with the reactant gases and catalyst surface over all the prepared catalysts, have been studied at a constant temperature 973K from 5000–50000mLg−1 h−1, in terms of total flow rate, with the constant feed ratio of CH4/CO2/He=1: 1: 8. As shown in Fig. 7a and b both CH4 and CO2 conversions decrease slightly with increasing GHSV due to the reduced contact time however, there is a little variation in the H2/CO ratio with increasing GHSV. Essentially, taking the inverse effect of the GHSV parameter for the DRM process into account, lower GHSV (10,000mLg−1 h−1) has been employed in the present study. The methane and carbon dioxide conversion in all the samples increase with increasing temperature demonstrating the endothermic nature of the methane dry reforming reaction (shown in Fig. 7c and 7d). At lower temperature regions, owing to the Reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) and methanation reaction, CO2 conversion exceeds over methane conversion. However, an opposite trend, i.e., greater methane conversion, has been observed at temperatures greater than 973K in all catalysts, due to methane decomposition which is predominant at higher temperatures [16,25]. The H2/CO ratio increases with an increase in the reaction temperature owing to the occurrence of the H2 producing water gas shift reaction (WGS), and methane decomposition. These side reactions are favoured at higher temperatures, which increase the H2/CO ratio. While at lower temperatures the H2 consuming RWGS reaction and methanation, reduce the H2/CO ratio [33]. A syngas ratio close to 1 is favoured between 873 and 973K, as shown in Fig. 7 c, and the corresponding conversion of methane and carbon dioxide has been shown in Fig. 7d. Although the syngas ratio increases from 773Kand the maximum value attains at 1073K, it is preferable to employ the reaction temperature at 973K, in viewing the higher catalytic activity with equal H2/CO ratio and no coke deposition. The difference in initial catalytic activity between the various synthesized catalysts with different acidity-basicity ratio, resulting from the synthetic procedure, clearly indicates that nature of the surface (acidity-basicity) has pronounced effect upon the catalytic activity. Experiments have been conducted to study the long-term stability of the catalysts. For these experiments, a reaction temperature of 973K has been selected on the basis of energy consumption, activity and the optimal H2/CO ratio of syngas. The results are presented in, in Fig. 8 . Each of the catalysts at the beginning shows the higher conversion of both methane and carbon dioxide with H2/CO ratio in syngas equal to unity, except for the stepwise synthesized TsNiAl and Ni/Com silica for which H2/CO ratio of syngas is lower than unity. The lowering in H2/CO ratio is due to the simultaneous occurrence of the RWGS reaction. This is consistent with the higher acidic nature of the catalyst surfaces, and in good agreement with the findings of Grenoble et al. according to whom increasing surface acidity favours the RWGS [34], which reduced the H2/CO ratio. The water selectivity of the various surface tuned catalysts followed the order Ni/Com silica>TsNiAl>OsNiSi>TsNiSi>OsNiAl≈Ni/ComMgO, consistent with the surface acid/base ratio of the various catalysts. The above data clearly indicates, that any daviation in the surface acid base ratio from an intermediate value of ∼2, promote RWGS as side reactions (except higher basicity as in the case of Ni/Com MgO). The OsNiAl, and Ni/ComMgO produce no water during the time on stream (TOS) study, for which, the homogeneous distribution of surface acidity-basicity enhances the rate of methane cracking at the acidic sites and the deposited carbon oxidised by lattice oxygen come from CO2 in the basic sites in OsNiAl and in excess basicity of Ni/Com MgO responsible. The oxygen uptake capacity of the various catalysts also dependent on the basicity of the catalysts, and both followed the same order. For the DRM, being an endothermic reaction, higher conversion of reactants have been attained only at higher temperatures, however, at high temperatures coke deposition decreased the catalyst activity. The carbon deposition over the catalysts has been determined by carbon balance, according to Eq. (6), which was found to follow the order Ni/Com silica<TsNiAl<OsNiSi≈TsNiSi<OsNiAl≈Ni/ComMgO. The higher carbon deposition upon Ni/Com silica and TsNiAl is due to the lower basicity mitigated by its higher acidity. This reduced the rate of CO2 adsorption on the highly acidic catalyst surface. Lesser CO2 adsorption produced very small surface adsorbed oxygen. Therefore, the carbon over the metal surface does not oxidize by surface oxygen and deactivate rapidly. The one step synthesized OsNiAl and highly basic TsNiSi and Ni/Com MgO, being more basic in nature, suffered from less coke deposition. The OsNiAl showed a homogeneous distribution of acidic and basic sites, strong metal support interaction, owing to very small nickel particle size among all the tested catalysts system. The coke deposited on acidic site has been easily removed by surface oxygen from basic site owing to CO2 disproportionation. In the catalysts with higher basicity, a large amount of CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface, which hindered the next reactant molecule to come into contact with the catalyst surface as well as surface oxygen from CO2 on disproportionation, oxidize the metal and hence deactivate the catalyst [9]. Fig. 9 shows the variation of turnover frequency (TOF) and activation energy (Ea) of methane and carbon dioxide with surface acidity-basicity. The observed results (provided in the supporting information) are in a great deal of the activity measurement study. At higher surface acidity, methane activation energy is very small in comparison to carbon dioxide. This made methane cracking dominant at the acidic surface over other side reactions. This lead to catalyst deactivation by coke deposition and the TOF becomes lower. At higher surface basicity, carbon dioxide activation energy became less than methane activation energy. This made Boudouard reaction with simultaneous occurring metal oxidation predominant, which also lead to deactivation and lowered the TOF. In intermediate acidity-basicity (acid/base ratio ∼2), the homogeneous distribution of acidic and basic sites, strong metal support interaction with very small Ni nanoparticles made Ea of both the reactants comparable. This made the rate of methane cracking comparable with carbon dioxide splitting. Therefore, the surface oxygen coming from CO2 has easily removed the carbon deposited over the active nickel. This provides higher TOF and long term stability in DRM. 3.3 Characterization of the spent catalysts To gain some insight into the effect of surface acidity basicity on DRM, the catalysts after 100h study at 700°C have also been characterised by various techniques. The pore size distribution and N2 physisorption analyses have been performed on used catalysts, and the results are shown on Fig. 10 a and b. Table 1 clearly demonstrates the lower surface area of the spent catalysts in comparison to the fresh catalysts and indicates the occurrence of coke deposition on the active surface. However, the spent OsNiAl sample shows almost no change in the surface area and pore size distribution, in comparison to its fresh counterpart, thus confirming that the mesoporous framework is stable for 100h. All the catalysts showed a characteristic decrease in pore volume with increasing pore diameter, due to the deposition of coke on the mesopores of the active catalysts. This, along with coke deposition upon the active nickel particle, is likely to be the cause of the deactivation of the catalysts. However in the catalysts with higher basicity, the surface area, pore volume and pore diameter do not vary so much. This indicats that these catalysts neither deactivated by coke deposition nor by Boudourd reaction but mainly by metal oxidation from lattice oxygen comes from CO2 splitting on the surface. To gain an understanding of the effect of TOS on the catalysts, with variable surface acidity-basicity, scanning electron microscopy investigation has been performed on all the samples after the 100h stability tests. Fig. 11 represents the SEM images of each of the catalysts. It is interesting to note that the two-step synthesized catalysts TsNiAl, shows carbon growth after the long-term stability analysis, while no carbon formation observed in one-step synthesized catalysts. The TEM analysis in Fig. 12 also reveals a clear difference between the spent catalysts. The presence of carbon nanotube in two-step synthesized TsNiAl, commercial catalyst Ni/Com silica concludes, higher acidity favours catalyst deactivation by methane cracking. The absence of any carbon species in TsNiSi and commercial catalyst Ni/Com MgO indicated the deactivation of these catalysts ismainly due to oxidation of active metal, which further does not take part in the reaction. The one step synthesized catalysts OsNiAl, and OsNiSi showes adamant metal support interaction, with a uniform distribution of acidic and basic sites, the rate of carbon deposition by methane cracking reaction equals to the rate of carbon oxidation by surface oxygen to CO. Hence the one step synthesized catalysts have been found to show higher activity in DRM. Metal oxidation, methane decomposition upon the active surface and Boudourd reaction are considered as the main barrier of a catalyst towards long term catalytic activity in DRM. Ni+O→NiO CH4 →C+2H2 ΔH=75KJ/mol 2CO→C+CO2 ΔH=−171KJ/mol The carbon deposited over active nickel particle might be the adsorbed atomic carbon, amorphous carbon, or whisker carbon. Therefore, the type carbon present in the spent catalysts is crucial to understand the catalyst deactivation. The carbon deposited over the catalysts has been analyzed using TG, DTG, O2-TPO and H2-TPH (Table 4 ). The difference in coke deposition upon the catalyst surfaces is due to the difference in surface acidity-basicity, which controls the metal support interaction, metal dispersion over the surface and metal particle size. The coke deposited over all the catalysts after 100h TOS study has been determined by TG, DTG and presented in Fig. 13 . In the thermogravimetric analysis, the weight loss at ∼373–473K is due to physisorbed water. The presence of water vapour produced during the reaction caused hydroxylation of the nickel oxide [35]. Hence, the next mass loss is due to the phase change of Ni(OH)2 to NiO at ∼473–673K. The mass loss above 673K is due to the removal of coke deposited on the active metal surface during the TOS study. In the thermogravimetric analysis, this deposited coke has been oxidised between 673 and 1053K. Two apparent mass loss occurred at ∼723K and ∼940K, indicating the presence of two different types of carbonaceous species in the spent catalysts. It has been accepted that inert whisker carbonaceous species requires a higher temperature for oxidation compared to reactive amorphous carbon deposited on the catalyst surface. The mass loss at 723K is attributed to the oxidation of the surface amorphous carbon, an active species in the formation of synthesis gas [36]. Among the catalysts tested in the CO2 reforming of methane, the weight loss of the various catalysts followed the trend Ni/Com silica>TsNiAl>TsNiSi>OsNiSi≈Ni/Com MgO≈OsNiAl. This is concomitant with the previous results obtained, which showed that deviation of surface acid base ratio from an intermediate value caused coke deposition upon the catalyst surfaces. For Ni/Com MgO and TsNiSi catalysts, owing to their higher basicity produced more surface adsorbed oxygen which hindered coke deposition upon the active metal surface. However, more CO2 adsorbed and cracking on the surface caused a slight carbon deposition by Boudourd reaction as well as increases the rate of active metal oxidation, which lead to catalyst deactivation. In one step synthesized OsNiAl catalyst, the rate of methane cracking reaction in the acidic surface has been oxidised by the surface oxygen [37]. Therefore, a balance between carbon deposition and removal provids long term catalyst stability. The removal of carbon by surface oxygen depends on the rate of oxygen transfer in the catalyst. In one step synthesize catalyst stronger interaction between metal and support surface with intermediate acidity-basicity, where methane decomposition occurs at the acidic site and CO2 decomposition occur at basic sites, accelerate the availability of surface oxygen with the removal of carbon upon the active metal sites, thus provide higher stability, whereas in twostep synthesize catalysts with imbalanced acidic and basic site and weak metal support interaction the oxygen transfer becomes tough, results in deactivation through active metal oxidation and carbon growth by Boudourd reaction. This has been further confirmed by CHN analysis, carried out to understand the total amount of carbon deposition during the reaction, and the data shown in Table 5 . The result supports TG, TPO, and TPH (given in supporting info). One step synthesized catalysts showed very less coke deposition, in comparison to the twostep synthesis one. The favorable distribution of acidic/basic sites in one step synthesises catalysts readily oxidize the surface carbon, while due to imbalanced acidic/basic sites in twostep synthesis catalysts, the coke deposited upon the active sites does not easily oxidize and lead catalyst deactivation. Based on the characterization results with activity measurement studies over the different catalyst with variable surface acidity-basicity, a sequence of probable mechanistic steps of reaction mechanism and carbon growth in DRM over nickel based catalysts with variable acid/base ratio has been derived in Scheme 1 . The most important step is the methane activation, occurs mainly on the metal sites (step 1 in Scheme 1). The activation of methane occurs via dissociative adsorption of methane [38] upon the acidic sites (step 2 in Scheme 1). The activation of mildly acidic CO2 occurs at basic surface sites, results in a formation of MgOCO2 (step 3 in Scheme 1). The MgOCO2 additive transfer this CO2 to ceria results in the formation of a ceria oxycarbonates (step 4 in Scheme 1). The cerium oxycarbonate then reduced by the surface hydrogen comes from catalytic cracking of methane on the acidic surface to produce H2O and CO (step 5 in Scheme 1). The H2O later oxidize the deposited carbon upon the metal surface, to produce syngas simultaneously. At higher acidity of support surface methane decomposition predominates over all reactions, leads catalyst deactivation (step 6 in Scheme 1) while a significant amount of CO2 adsorbed on the basic sites leads a layer of CO2 around the catalyst surface, hinders the reactants to come into contact with the catalyst surface also leads catalyst deactivation through Boudouard reaction as well as active metal oxidation by surface oxygens and gets deactivated. Table 6 shows the qualitative comparison of acid-base delimited catalysts with prevailing catalysts. Due to the absence of directly comparable results on surface acidity-basicity, we compared our data with different nickel based catalysts. These results showed that the CH4 and CO2 conversions observed on acid-base delimited catalysts are somewhat higher than the values reported in the recent literature under comparable conditions. The data showed that OsNiAl and OsNiSi produced higher CH4 and CO2 conversion along with a higher H2/CO ratio than other catalysts. TsNiAl showed poor performance, exhibiting much lower values for reactant conversion. 4 Conclusion In this study, two sets of catalysts with different acid/base surface properties have been prepared each by a different synthesis procedure. The performance of these catalysts in the DRM has been studied, and the results for each have been compared. On the basis of these results, combined with detailed characterization of the catalytic materials before and after use, following predictions have been made. 1) One step synthesized surface provides a better balance between the acidic and basic sites than that of the two-step synthesized catalyst 2) The excessive surface acidity of the support leads to catalyst deactivation through methane decomposition. Similarly, excessive surface basicity leads to catalyst deactivation through the Boudouard reaction as well as through formation of metal oxides. 3) The homogeneous distribution of Ceria and Magnesia contributor to the moderate surface acidic and basic sites on catalyst surface plays a crucial role in determining catalyst long term stability. In methane cracking reactions, carbon deposits over the active sites, and simultaneously gets oxidised by surface oxygen from CO2 disproportionation, which improves the catalyst stability. 4) In a catalytic system with increasing surface acidity, methane activation energy decreases that enhances the rate of methane decomposition simultaneously with increasing surface basicity CO2 activation energy increases, leads to higher CO2 disproportionation. Therefore, a moderate acidity- basicity, where both methane and carbon dioxide have comparable activation energy favours CO2 reforming of methane without any deactivation. coredata.dc:description: The correlation between surface acidity-basicity and catalyst deactivation have been investigated in the CO2 reforming of methane by adjusting the surface properties of the catalyst. Silica and alumina based support with different acidity-basicity have been prepared by two methods, (i) a solvothermal method and (ii) a sequential impregnation method. Then each of the supports has been decorated with Ni nanoparticles followed by variation of their activity towards CO2 reforming of methane (DRM). The catalytic materials have been analyzed before and after reaction by a variety of analytical techniques including BET, XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD, O2-TPD, TG, O2-TPO, H2-TPH, SEM, and TEM. Catalysts with higher acidity were found to promote methane-cracking reactions, while the Boudouard and deactivation owing to metal oxidation were dominant at high basicity. Catalysts with more acidic or basic surfaces were found to be more prone to deactivation and metal sintering. The turnover frequency (TOF) and activation energy (Ea) of both the reactants showed a Gaussian curve with acidity-basicity of the catalyst surfaces. Among the tested catalysts, the best performing was those with homogeneous dispersion of surface acidic and basic sites, prepared by a single step synthesis. In contrast, under the same conditions, two-step synthesized supports with the significantly imbalanced distribution of acidic and basic sites favoured the Reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, active metal oxidation by surface adsorbed oxygen and hence deactivated rapidly.
coredata.dc:title: A study of the synergy between support surface properties and catalyst deactivation for CO2 reforming over supported Ni nanoparticles
